1 Origin of Agile

Demand risk. Delivery risk.

You get feedback on your process, and adapt according to the feedback.

Everything was waterfall approach in the past.

Customer demands are moving.

2 Agile Manifesto

Companies were too focussed on documenting and planning. A document of 68 words drove the new paradigm. It's called the Agile Manifesto.

http://agilemanifesto.org/

3 What is scrum?

Breaking work down in to smaller units of work.

Split the product, split the team, split the time.

Scrum is a framework, not a methodology.

http://www.scrumguides.org

4 The Product Owner

Malik is the product owner and knows the problem. We have stakeholders. Malik wants the stakeholders to love the product. He will create user stories. Users will be able to search for homes. Malik will get bombarded with lots of ideas. He can add these to the backlog. All these ideas can get unmanageable in the backlog. Malik passes the stories on to the development team. Malik has to decide what to say no to. PO decides what is in and what is out. He doesn't do this alone, he does it with a scrum team. The dev team should have access to the stakeholders if they need it.

The PO maximises the value of the product. He prioritises the stories. Malik needs to know the value of the stories. Some are critical, while some are nice to have. Some are huge and some are small. Build the small ones with high value first. Malik might have to guess some of this.

How does the product owner build the backlog? It's hard.

4.1 Create a backlog

Things start with ideas and hypothesis. Does a problem exist? Will this add value to users? Can we solve this problem? It needs to be usable.

Bring the right people in to the room. The PO can't do this by themselves. PO looks after value. Engineering lead looks after feasible. UX lead on usable.

4.2 Product Backlog

An in order (prioritized) list of features, sometimes written as a story. It can include defects, spikes, and technical (upgrade).

4.3 Characteristics of a good product backlog

This can get messy quickly. You should have a schedule to tidy the backlog.

D - detail appropriately E - emergent E - estimated P - prioritized

Items are not always at the same level of detail. Lots of detail should be at the top of the backlog. This happens in a just-in-time fashion. We shouldn't give a lot of detail to stories that are far away in time, as things could change. This is the emergent. Being continously being updated as information becomes available.

Estimated - size estimate to the effort required.

Prioritized - it should be prioritized, especially the items at the top.

4.4 Grooming the Backlog

Adding, deleting and refining the backlog. Estimating. Prioritizing.

Who does this?

It's a team effort by scrum team. And stakeholders. The PO is the grooming decision making. It leads to a good dialogue between the team, when it is a team effort. 5-10% time should be given to PO grooming activities.

4.5 How to Write good Stories

3c's.

  1. Card - small with limited space. Has a couple of sentences for later discussions. As a <user> I want <something> so that <reason>.
  2. Conversation - have a convo to flesh out the details (kick-off)?
  3. Confirmation - acceptance criteria - definition of done? (Tests related).

Stories are not the only place for requirements. Visual design, a chart, or any other documentation. They should be easy to refine.

They can be at different levels of granuality. Large stories are epics. This becomes a container for more stories. Stories fit in to a sprint. Tasks can fit in to a story. Tasks are smaller than stories. PO doesn't really care about a task as it is not delivered.

It's good to agree when a story is ready to be brought forward - with a definition of done.

4.6 Definition of Ready

  • Independent
  • Negotiable
  • Valuable
  • Estimable
  • Small
  • Testable

(INVEST).

5 Role of Scrum Master

Focussed on helping everyone embrace the scrum principles. They teach the team to solve their own problems. Servant leader, what can I do to help you be more effective?

  • coach
  • servant leader
  • inteference
  • impediments
  • change agent

What skills should they have?

  • knowledgable
  • patient
  • protective
  • collaborative
  • transparent

A talented scrum master could act as a developer at the same time. They can also be the product owner. This is not a great move at all.

6 Preparing for Sprint Planning

6.1 Checklist

  1. groomed backlog - good stories
  2. up to date product roadmap
  3. definition of done
  4. sprint goal

6.2 Pre-planning Meeting

We have a category of Epics, Almost ready PBIs, and ready PBIs. What is the length of each sprint? 1 - 4 weeks. Malik needs to walk through the backlog items. Do an initual estimation for each story in the backlog, due for the sprint.

6.2.1 Silent estimation

  • get team
  • explain items
  • ask team to sort cards into line smallest effort at top
  • they do this quietly
  • the cards stop moving around eventually
  • use fibonacci sequence
  • group items of similar size
  • then assign the story points to each fibonacci number
  • stories that move a lot can have more discussion

The PO is not involved in story estimation.

A story point is relative effort.
